title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and other employees who responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center in New York City are acknowledged. The tragic events of September 11, 2001, resulted in the heroic actions of individuals at the World Trade Center in New York City, the Pentagon in Washington, DC, and on United Airlines Flight 93. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 took heroic and noble action to prevent the aircraft from being used as a weapon during the unprecedented attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 prevented the aircraft from being used as a weapon during the 9/11 attacks. It is fitting to recognize their sacrifice with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices on and after September 11, 2001. This includes personal representatives or next of kin, the Flight 93 National Memorial Project, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, and the Pentagon Memorial Project. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for the Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal, representing those who lost their lives in the attacks at the Flight 93 National Memorial Project, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, and the Pentagon Memorial Project. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for the Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal, honoring those who lost their lives in the attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93, and the Pentagon. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for the Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal, honoring those who lost their lives in the attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93 in rural Pennsylvania, and the Pentagon. The design consultation will involve the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties. The Secretary of the Treasury will consult with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties to design silver and gold medals for individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Eligibility for the medal includes individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001, within the United States. Individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of terrorism within the United States are eligible to receive gold medals. Eligibility is determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS. The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of medals for officers, emergency workers, and employees of government agencies, to be displayed at their duty stations in memory of those assigned there on September 11, 2001. Persons referred to in this subsection are officers, emergency workers, and other employees of government agencies who responded to the 9/11 attacks and perished as a direct result of the act of terrorism. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible to receive a medal and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible recipients for a medal and duplicate medal, consulting various organizations for determinations. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible recipients for a medal and duplicate medal, consulting various organizations for determinations. The lists are not subject to judicial review. If an individual becomes eligible for a medal or a recipient becomes eligible for a duplicate medal, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
